awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Optimizing Incentives for Carbon Capture and Storage Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports fundamental research to provide new knowledge toward understanding the effect of market-based incentives on the implementation of carbon capture and storage systems for reducing carbon emissions from coal and natural gas power plants. The results of this research can help policy makers evaluate proposed policies dealing with carbon capture and storage methods.  Additionally, the research program encourages underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students to become researchers and will broaden science, technology, engineering and mathematics participation. The program provides pre-college students the opportunity to participate in an interactive educational activity involving both environmental science and operations management. Overall, the results from this research will benefit education at all levels from pre-college to post-graduate. The data and code developed under this award will be shared with the research community.

The research objective of this project is to determine the effect of market-based incentives on the implementation of carbon capture and storage technology through theoretical extensions of mechanism design and simulation optimization. The research team will investigate the intrinsic relationships among contract prices and quantities, cost structures, and emissions profiles using a mechanism design framework. This approach will help the storage operator decide which emissions sources to serve, what contract prices and quantities to offer to induce emission sources to participate, and what pipeline capacity to build. This research will also examine the impact of a cap-and-trade policy by incorporating permit trading explicitly in the decisions of carbon capture and storage participants, and compare the efficiency against that of a carbon tax policy. Lastly, the team will create a simulation optimization framework to optimize contract design when data is available but the mechanism design formulation is analytically intractable.

por.por_cntn:
This research program examined the effect of market-based incentives on the implementation of the carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology through theoretical extensions of mechanism design and simulation optimization. To investigate the incentives needed to induce the participation of both a storage operator and emitters, a new principal-agent (PA) framework was developed. This framework allows for both ex-ante and ex-post information asymmetry between the principal and the agent. It is used to assess the impact of uncertainty in emissions quantities on the pricing of CO2 storage while considering agents who have heterogeneous emissions profiles, are offered with flexible contracts, and are imposed by emissions regulations. A method of deriving closed-form solutions from numerical results was introduced and its viability was established with nonlinear utility functions. New solution structures were identified and used to quantify the incentives the principal needs to offer for the agents to participate and capture the desired emissions quantities. Further, multiple versions of flexible contracts (forced participation vs. allowing non-participation, differentiated vs. aggregated) and various emissions policies (marginal carbon tax, cap-and-trade, and common carbon pricing) were analyzed in terms of the overall CO2 quantity stored, the CCS operator's profitability, and the social welfare. As a result, new knowledge on their effectiveness in inducing the participation and storage efforts of the CCS operator and emitters was generated. Separately, a solution method of using sample average approximation and bootstrapping was proposed to solve a PA problem where the agent's type is continuous. Its applicability was demonstrated using a CCS example.

This project provided training to both graduate and undergraduate students in operations research and economics. A learning module on building a CCS optimization network was developed for pre-college students and over two hundred students attended this workshop.  The proposed research is completed, and results have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journal publications and a conference proceeding.
